COMMENT_TX: Moved his entrance to after the error, which was charged to Lumpe
ej,wickd101,P,hallb901,Bench jockeying $Tigers Wickersham, not in game, ejected by HP umpire Haller sometime in game for bench jockeying
Most runs; most hits; biggest inning to date for Senators.
Temperature dropped to 54 by the 9th inning.

The scorer says that Versalles scored on Hall's single and Valdespino scored from second on an 'FC'.  Hall is only credited with one RBI on the play.  I'm guessing that the 'FC' was on either Oliva or Hall on a cutoff throw to the infield.  All the runners were safe and Valdespino scored.

No details are given about this play other than Mincher scored and Kindall went to second on an error by Terry Fox. The error didn't occur on a hit ball, so I guessed it was some sort of pickoff attempt.
The scoresheet says D7+E7, but Twins centerfielder Joe Nossek is charged with the error in the game summary totals, not Bob Allison.  Check at end of season Changed to E8
E4 may mean bunt with 4 covering first and dropped
It's hard to visualize how Kaline was caught between third and home when he started on second, but that's the way it's written.
Rhubarb over throwing at players; Linz ejected
$Mantle thrown out for tossing bat and helmet

Unclear as to what happened here.  The Twins scorer provides no details at all; the Tigers scorer seems to indicate that Oliva advanced on Allison's strikeout.  Somewhere there was also an error on the Tiger thirdbaseman without the ball being put into play.  I lumped both advancements and the E5 together to account for everything.  This one may require more research. Tiger catcher Bill Freehan is credited by the Twins scorer with an assist although it can't be found anywhere on the scoresheet.  The CS3(2E5) would account for it . . . Changed to OA - Versalles was not CS in game.
Exact timing of wild pitch unclear.
I credited Terry Fox with a save under the 1969 rule even though neither scorer annotated it.
$Al Kaline was hurt making a diving attempt to catch Battey's line drive to left-center
The Minnesota scorer says 1-3, the Detroit scorer says 6-3.
Hit location unclear; appears to be an infield single.

It's unclear as to how this play actually happened.  The Detroit scorer has a notation that may indicate Quilici as a pinch runner.  Quilici certainly came in as a defensive replacement in the bottom of the inning.  If Quilici was NOT a pinch runner, then the putout COULD have been on Valdespino being caught in a rundown following his single. i.e. S8.2-H;BX2(263)? This is my best guess as to what happened . . . Quilici was not a PR, so we go with plan B
